reviewText: I did a little research concerning Stan Meyer (one of the subjects of this video). The man was, in fact, a well-known fraud and prosecuted as such back in 1996 -- a fact conveniently ignored by the producer. This is pseudo-documentary totally devoid of any real science or detailed explanations as to the physical nature and properties of water.  Since Mr. Meyer died in 1998, I'm a little confused as to when this broadcast was produced since the credits give a the date as 2009.The entire discussion regarding "zero point energy" was laughable!  I've heard better explanations from Dr. Rodney McKay of Stargate Atlantis fame! Virtually all nuclear physicists reject the notion that one can "tap" into ZPE; ZPE is a quantum mechanical phenomenon, not a source of energy like a car battery.Never the less, current theory in this area apparently opens up a few loop-holes that THEORETICALLY could allow for some type of energy extraction. A couple of guys (Haisch & Moddel)were convinced they could take advantage of these loop-holes to develop an energy extraction device; they were awarded a patent in 2008 for their "Quantum Vacuum Energy Extraction" device.  They claim: "The disclosed devices are scalable in size and energy output for applications ranging from replacements for small batteries to power plant sized generators of electricity." Why wasn't this mentioned in the video? These guys  work at the Jovian Corporation (a spin-off from the University of Colorado) and have apparently received money from DARPA and private investors. Haisch & Moddel are not backyard inventors and certainly don't appear to be scammers, but they ARE butting heads with some big names in the physics world.  All this stuff is still highly-theoretical and, though well intentioned, the work on Quantum Vacuum Energy may very well yield a big goose egg.Here's a web sight describing the theory and the devices:  [...]This website from caltech explains the concept zero point energy and the zero point field.[...]I learned far more in 15-min of internet searching than the watching this dumb 52-min video. It was sad to see Author C. Clarke used in such a sordid way. If this stuff is theoretically doable, then it's not going to be easy and some dude working in his garage certainly is NOT going come up with a device on his own.  These kinds of things require huge investments and major institutional support.  I'm talking about something on the scale of the Manhattan Project or the more recent effort to identify the famous "God particle", the Higgs-Boson.

reviewText: This extraordinary documentary tells the story of a small group of inventors who are seeking in various ways to unlock the vast amounts of energy locked up...in water! Ordinary everyday water. A vast untapped storehouse of one of the greatest fuels in the universe, hydrogen. At first their efforts were ignored by scientists, but steadily their work has won recognition. If only a fraction of their hopes were to be realized, untold amounts of clean energy would become available to future generations. This documentary tells an intriguing story that no one else has tracked, and in relation to which no one can predict the outcome.

reviewText: An interesting, albeit poorly done documentary. The approach is too gentle about how rabidly the scientific establishment attacks anything even remotely approaching this arena, and seems to be stuck on the idea that "science" or the scientific establishment is the accepted and unassailable arbiter of reality. We must remember that science is always way behind the curve, due to the nature of replicating and studying breakthroughs. This is why scientists seldom make real breakthroughs, only find more details about what is already "known."The idea that "science" knows how just about everything works is wildly inaccurate, to put it nicely. In point of fact, our models of how the world works are only as accurate as our current instrumentation and social/political paradigms allow. For example, of the nearly 200 documented effects of magnetism, current science can only explain about half, or around 100. Nearly 100 magnet effects remain unexplained under our current paradigms. Our system of electromagnetics taught to electrical engineers is over 150 years old, and dates to "modified" Maxwell's equations created around the time of the Civil War, before the discovery of the electron or broken symmetry, and have yet to be corrected.We simply do not know as much as some people would have you believe. You wouldn't get this impression from the arrogance of the scientific establishment. There are many social, political, and economic agendas at work in holding back information and certain kinds of technological progress. Some of them, like the prospect of weaponizing new energy, do have some merit. The issue of such conspiracies is a very big, very deep topic.There are many books which detail the problems with the scientific establishment, and show how it actually retards progress rather than leads it. For example:Alternative Science: Challenging the Myths of the Scientific EstablishmentAgainst MethodThe Tyranny of ScienceThe Structure of Scientific Revolutions: 50th Anniversary EditionIt also barely mentions the deep political and economic factors, although they do mention the government's "march in" rights to steal technology and patents.The one big error that virtually everyone in the film makes is to confuse "efficiency" with "Coefficient Of Performance," or COP. It is not possible, even by simple definition and language, to exceed 100 percent efficiency - to have more energy come out of a system than is put into it from all sources. That is not so much a "law of physics" as it is a simple fact of language and the definition of a system.Coefficient of performance, on the other hand, deals with the difference between the energy the operator puts into a system and the total energy output of the system. Heat pumps, for example, have an efficiency of around 50 percent (only 50 percent of the total energy input does the intended work), but a COP or 3 or 4. In other words, the operator gets 3 or 4 times the energy output from a heat pump than they put in to run it. The rest is "harvested" from the environment - another source. A sailboat or wind turbine has a COP of nearly infinity, but does not exceed 100 percent efficiency, or even get close to that figure.Not understanding these two terms causes most of difficulty and confusion talking about these systems. It is never possible to go past 100 percent efficiency, but it is quite possible to get more energy out of a system than the operator is using to run it. Large parts of our technology depend on that very thing. If one is using the term COP correctly, we have all kinds of "overunity" systems in operation every day, like heat pumps and sailboats."Overunity" is a poor term for any energy system, and the term "Zero Point Energy" is so overused and misused that many people no longer even pay attention to it. All kinds of New Age flakes have adopted these terms, as they do many "scientific" terms, in order to sound modern and "with it," as well as to fake being scientific. (Because they, too, think that science is the ultimate arbiter of reality. Wrong.)While there are some interesting parts of the film, there is much better information in the work of people like Tom Bearden, web sites like PESwiki, and magazines like Infinite Energy.Energy from the Vacuum: Concepts & PrinciplesDon't let the poor quality of this film stop you from looking into new energy sources. Go to better sources and realize that the mainstream has many, many reasons to lie to you about all this (and it will).
